channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #231 - Ho ho ho!
item.description:
Christmas arrived, and Perl 6 has had its first public release. Unsurprisingly there are a lot of Perl 6 things in this week's issue.

Plenty of Perl 5 too, which is probably going to be the pattern from now on.

This is the last issue of 2015, so from all of the editors: best wishes for 2016.

Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: An Unexpectedly Long-expected Party
item.description: Larry's post that lets us know that Christmas has arrived.

item.title: Christmas is here
item.description: The official announcement of the Christmas release of Rakudo Perl 6.

item.title: Reflecting, celebrating, and looking forward
item.description: Jonathan's reflects on his journey with Perl 6 so far, and what comes next.

item.title: Perl 6 lives!
item.description: Damian waxes lyrical on Perl 6.

item.title: Dr Strangecode, or how to stop worrying and learn to love Perl 6!
item.description: Kaare's reflections on Perl 6, where he wonders who's going to use it, and what niche is it going to make its own?

item.title: The Perl6 Gold Rush Began
item.description: Tudor's thoughts on how to get involved with Perl 6 and contribute something.

item.title: Perl6's newline translation behavior has been fixed
item.description: Two weeks ago we include a post from Sinan, where he pointed out some unexpected behaviour with handling of newlines in Perl 6. Sinan happily reports that it was fixed in time for Christmas.

item.title: Perl6 and CPAN
item.description: There's no official plan for a CPAN equivalent for Perl 6, but that's mainly because there are no official plans for pretty much anything in the Perl universe :-) Justin has been exploring whether PAUSE and MetaCPAN can provide Perl 6 support on CPAN.

item.title: 2015.52: Closer and closer to the Release
item.description: It feels like an awful lot has happened since this was posted, as this is talking about the run-up to the Christmas release of Perl 6, but I still included it for completeness.

item.title: P5P Summary: December 14th-20th
item.description: As ever, bugs were reported and fixed. Amongst the discussions was one on whether Exporter should be given the ability to rename functions on import.

item.title: Perl 5 Advent
item.description: The last 4 module articles from the Perl 5 advent calendar this year covered feature, AnsibleModule, Mojo::UserAgent, and Device::Chip::Adapter. On the 25th, Mark posted a wrap-up, and pointed out useful resources for finding out more about CPAN.

item.title: Weâ€™re starting Learning Perl, 7th edition
item.description: Work is starting on the next edition of Learning Perl. If there are changes you'd like to see, this is the time to let brian know.

item.title: TeePee
item.description: Flavio introduces teepee — a command-line tool that takes JSON or YAML (eg retrieved from some API using curl) and lets you slice and dice parts of it.

item.title: Using a Perl module from Java
item.description: Perlito5 now supports calling Perl subroutines from Java.

item.title: Dancer 2: test tips with PostgreSQL
item.description: Pierre shares some tips for how you can test a Dancer2-based API that used PostgreSQL.

item.title: Dance With Swagger
item.description: Yanick has created Dancer::Plugin::Swagger, which makes life easier for people who want to use Swagger to document their Dancer-based APIs.

item.title: Medium-Scale Dancer application design
item.description: This is the first in a series of articles about working with Dancer. Each one links to the next part in the series.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Finally, a streaming Perl filehandle API for MongoDB GridFS
item.description: The latest development release of the MongoDB distribution includes a new interface to MongoDB's filesystem abstraction. David shows how you can use it.

item.title: Improving the water quality of the CPAN River
item.description: Discussion of metrics for indicating how appropriate CPAN distributions are for your CPAN distribution to depend on. I plan to use this as one of the things used to select distributions for the Pull Request Challenge, but also to see whether we improve the overall "water quality" of the River of CPAN in 2016.

item.title: Making MooseX::Storage Play Nice with Runtime Roles
item.description: Remember that scene in The Empire Strikes Back, where Leia says "I love you" to Han, and he coolly says "I know"? I thought of Yanick as Han Solo after I read this.

item.title: Join us next year at BuiltinPerl!
item.description: Amalia gives stats on the number of Perl-based companies listed on builtinperl.com, and and hopes that 2016 will see many more added.

item.title: riba2016 ends - now what?
item.description: Ribasushi's tilt campaign was unsuccessful. As a result he's going to step away from his CPAN distributions, but before he does there will be one last DBIx::Class release.

item.title: CPAN.io as a reference site
item.description: BOOK's proposal for CPAN.io to be a reference site for various CPAN-related documentation.

item.title: Grants Committee Changes, December 2015
item.description: Ben Tilly is stepping down from Grants Committee, after 10 years service. Thanks to Ben. Sawyer X has volunteered to take his place.

item.title: London Perl Workshop Videos
item.description: Videos of the talks from the London Perl Workshop, held in early December.

item.title: Fast, Parallel, or Reliable: Pick 3, a Tour of Elixir
item.description: A 50-minute introduction to Elixir, a functional, dynamic, strongly-typed language.
